required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of Two Different Approaches in the Surgical Treatment of Tubal Ectopic Pregnancy
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Conventional Laparoscopy and Natural Orifice Transluminal Endoscopic Surgery in the Surgical Treatment of Tubal Ectopic Pregnancy

brief_summary.textblock:
In this study we aim to compare conventional laparoscopy and natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery in the surgical treatment of ectopic pregnancy.
All the patients, with an indication of surgery for ectopic pregnancy, will be asked to participate in this clinical trial.
Indication of surgery will be based on clinical findings, ultrasound scans and serum hcg levels. There will be no exclusion criteria.
Duration of surgery, successful completion of the operation, intraoperative data and postoperative data will be collected.
All the patients will be asked to fill out quality of recovery-40 (QoR-40) questionnaire and 36-item short form health survey (SF-36) before surgery.
QoR-40 questionnaire will be repeated 24 hours after surgery and repeated every 24 hours until discharge. SF-36 will be repeated at 1-month follow-up visit. Patients will be also evaluated at postoperative 3-months, and female sexual function index will be asked to be filled-out.

primary_outcome.measure: Successful completion of surgery as intended
primary_outcome.time_frame: Intraoperative, from the beginning to the end of surgical intervention
primary_outcome.description: The completion of the surgery with the route planned without having to change the surgical route

primary_outcome.time_frame: During follow-up, after surgery until hcg level drops below 5 U/L, up to 1 month
During follow-up, after surgery until hcg level drops below 5 U/L, up to 1 month

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Preoperatively and Postoperative every 24 hours until discharge, expected to be up to 3 days following surgery
secondary_outcome.description: The Quality of Recovery 40 questionnaire will be self-administered by patients at different time points
Short form 36 item health survery (SF-36) questionnaire will be self-administered by patients at different time points

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Postoperative 2 hours, 6 hours, 12 hours, 24 hours, and every 24 hours until discharge (if the patient stays longer than 1 day at the hospital), , expected to be up to 3 days following surgery
secondary_outcome.description: Postoperative pain will be assessed on a 10-cm visual analog scale at different time points
Female sexual function index (FSFI) questionnaire will be self-administered by patients at postoperative 3-months

secondary_outcome.measure: The need for additional analgesic use
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Postoperative period until discharge, expected to be up to 3 days following surgery
secondary_outcome.description: Patients will be routinely administered pethidine hydrochloride 3x50 mg parenteral on the day of surgery. Starting from postoperative day 1 patients will be administered paracetamol 500 mg oral upon their request. In case of inadequate pain relief and the need for additional analgesic use will ve recorded.

arm_group.description: In this arm, patients will be treated via conventional laparoscopy

arm_group.arm_group_label: Transvaginal natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery
arm_group.description: In this arm, patients will be treated via transvaginal natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery

intervention.description: Patients will undergo removal of the affected tube
intervention.arm_group_label: Transvaginal natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adults over 18 years of age,
- Diagnosis of tubal ectopic pregnancy
- Patient's preference to undergo salpingectomy
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with contraindication to endoscopic surgery
- Refusal to sign informed consent.

facility.name: Ege University University Hospital, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology
